Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of No-Touch Saphenous Vein Grafts in Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence

Participants.evidence: Participants were patients undergoing CABG, with eligibility criteria including suitability for SV grafting. The study was conducted at multiple centers.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received NT SV grafts, while the control group received conventionally harvested SV grafts.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to compare the patency rates of NT SV grafts with conventionally harvested SV grafts.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was graft patency, assessed at 12 months postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 2655 patients were randomised, with 1328 in the NT group and 1327 in the control group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 1300 NT and 1295 control patients using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The NT group showed a significantly lower occlusion rate (3.7%) compared to the control group (6.5%), with an odds ratio of 0.56 (95% CI, 0.41–0.76; P <0.001).

Harms.evidence: Leg wound complications were reported in 1.3% of NT patients.
